cve_description.example: Microsoft .NET Framework 1.0 SP3, 1.1 SP1, 2.0 SP2, 3.5, 3.5.1, 4, and 4.5 does not properly validate function parameters, which allows remote attackers to execute arbitrary code via (1) a crafted XAML browser application (aka XBAP), (2) a crafted ASP.NET application, or (3) a crafted .NET Framework application, aka ".NET Framework Parameter Validation Vulnerability."

description.example: Microsoft .NET Framework 1.0 SP3, 1.1 SP1, 2.0 SP2, 3.5, 3.5.1, 4, and 4.5 does not properly validate function parameters, which allows remote attackers to execute arbitrary code via (1) a crafted XAML browser application (aka XBAP), (2) a crafted ASP.NET application, or (3) a crafted .NET Framework application, aka ".NET Framework Parameter Validation Vulnerability."

arch.description: The architecture of the operating system. Currently only `64-bit` is supported. This parameter can be omitted for Linux.

os_type.description: The operating system type. Supported values include CENTOS, SLES, RHEL, UBUNTU or WINDOWS.

os_name.description: A human readable name for the operating system.

os_version.description: The version of the Linux or Windows operating system to check. See below for a list of supported Windows operating systems.

software.description: A list of the applications to check for vulnerabilities

checksum.description: A checksum for the Windows application or Linux package. This should be unique within the API request.

product.description: The name of the Windows application or Linux package.

version.description: The version of the Windows application or Linux package to check.

release.description: The release version of the Linux package to check. Note: this is field should be omitted for Windows applications.

min_risk_meter_score.description: The minimum risk meter score for vulns to be returned; will not return any vulns with risk meter scores less than this value. A min_risk_meter_score of zero will return all vulns.

cpe_products.description: product part of CPE URIs associated with a vendor

cpe_vendors.description: vendor part of CPE URIs associated with a vendor

cpe_normalized_application_names.description: The architecture of the operating system. Currently only `64-bit` is supported. This parameter can be omitted for Linux.

cpe_mappings.description: The architecture of the operating system. Currently only `64-bit` is supported. This parameter can be omitted for Linux.

vendor_binary_information.description: The architecture of the operating system. Currently only `64-bit` is supported. This parameter can be omitted for Linux.

vendor.description: Vendor name collected from redistributable binary distributed by the vendor

product.description: Product name collected from redistributable binary distributed by the vendor

description.example: An out-of-bounds read was addressed with improved bounds checking. This issue is fixed in macOS Catalina 10.15.7, Security Update 2020-005 High Sierra, Security Update 2020-005 Mojave, iOS 14.0 and iPadOS 14.0. Processing a maliciously crafted USD file may lead to unexpected application termination or arbitrary code execution.

product_name.example: macOS Catalina 10.15.7 Security Update 2020-005 High Sierra Security Update 2020-005 Mojave

impact.example: Processing a maliciously crafted USD file may lead to unexpected application termination or arbitrary code execution

microsoft_vuln_inferenece_post_response_.description: An array of malware family information.

cve_description.example: A memory corruption vulnerability exists in the Windows DHCP clientwhen an attacker sends specially crafted DHCP responses to a client, aka 'Windows DHCP Client Remote Code Execution Vulnerability'. This CVE ID is unique from CVE-2019-0698, CVE-2019-0726.

description.example: A memory corruption vulnerability exists in the Windows DHCP client when an attacker sends specially crafted DHCP responses to a client, aka 'Windows DHCP Client Remote Code Execution Vulnerability'. This CVE ID is unique from CVE-2019-0698, CVE-2019-0726.

arch.description: The architecture of the operating system. Currently only `64-bit` is supported. This parameter can be omitted for Linux.

os_type.description: The operating system type. Supported values include CENTOS, SLES, RHEL, UBUNTU or WINDOWS.

os_name.description: A human readable name for the operating system.

os_version.description: The version of the Linux or Windows operating system to check. See below for a list of supported Windows operating systems.

min_risk_meter_score.description: The minimum risk meter score for vulns to be returned; will not return any vulns with risk meter scores less than this value. A min_risk_meter_score of zero will return all vulns.

include_unverified_versions.description: Whether or not to include inference results for Windows OSes whose data quality results have not yet been verified by our research team. Does not include results for those versions by default.

installed_kbs.description: List of KBs installed on the operating system. e.g: ["KB5005043", "KB5004948"]

get.description:
Returns Common Platform Enumeration (CPE) mappings for a given application based on the information that the application's vendor attached to the distributable binary, which can be retrieved via osquery.

🚧

Restricted Access

This API endpoint is a premium feature for selected partners.

To retrieve the vendor/product information from distributable binaries installed on a client machine, run this osquery command:

osqueryi --json "SELECT * FROM programs;"

This should produce JSON output which looks like this: 

[
  {
    "identifying_number":"",
    "install_date":"20210215",
    "install_location":"C:\Program Files (x86)\Microsoft\Edge\Application",
    "install_source":"",
    "language":"",
    "name":"Microsoft Edge",
    "publisher":"Microsoft Corporation",
    "uninstall_string":""C:\Program Files (x86)\Microsoft\Edge\Application\88.0.705.68\Installer\setup.exe" --uninstall --msedge --system-level --verbose-logging",
    "version":"88.0.705.68"
  },
  ...etc
]

The "publisher" and "name" outputs from osquery map to the "vendor_name" and "product_name" parameters on this API endpoint. In this case, "Microsoft Corporation" and "Microsoft Edge":

/v2/application_mappings/find_by_binary_information?vendor_name=Microsoft Corporation&product_name=Microsoft Edge

Results:

{
  "cpe_normalized_application_names": [
    "Microsoft Edge"
  ],
  "cpe_mappings": [
    {
      "cpe_vendor": "microsoft",
      "cpe_product": "edge"
    }
  ],
  "vendor_binary_information": [
    {
      "vendor": "Microsoft Corporation",
      "product": "Microsoft Edge"
    },
    {
      "vendor": "Microsoft",
      "product": "EDGE"
    }
    {
      "vendor": "Microsoft Corp",
      "product": "Microsoft Edge"
    }
    ...etc
  ],
  "cpe_application_names": [
    "Microsoft Edge 88.0.705.50",
    "Microsoft Edge 88.0.705.62",
    "Microsoft Edge 88.0.705.63"
    ...etc
  ],
  "cpes": [
    {
      "product_version": "-",
      "cpe_uri": "cpe:/a:microsoft:edge:-",
      "cpe_uri_format": "2.2"
    },
    {
      "product_version": null,
      "cpe_uri": "cpe:/a:microsoft:edge",
      "cpe_uri_format": "2.2"
    },
    {
      "product_version": "88.0.705.50",
      "cpe_uri": "cpe:/a:microsoft:edge:88.0.705.50",
      "cpe_uri_format": "2.2"
    },
    {
      "product_version": "88.0.705.62",
      "cpe_uri": "cpe:/a:microsoft:edge:88.0.705.62",
      "cpe_uri_format": "2.2"
    },
    ...etc
  ]
}

Given an application name and an optional vendor name, this endpoint executes a wildcard search against all CPE application titles and returns any matching CPE mappings.

🚧

Restricted Access

This API endpoint is a premium feature for selected partners.

For example, if searching with cpe_title = "Microsoft Internet Explorer 88.0.1008.3", this endpoint will ignore the version and return all CPE mappings with titles containing "Microsoft Internet Explorer". Ex: 

{
  "cpe_normalized_application_names": [
    "Microsoft Internet Explorer",
    "Microsoft Internet Explorer SP1",
    "Microsoft Internet Explorer SP2",
    "Microsoft Internet Explorer Platform Preview 1.0 (PP1)",
    "Microsoft Internet Explorer SP3",
    "...etc"
  ],
  "cpe_mappings": [
    {
      "cpe_vendor": "microsoft",
      "cpe_product": "ie"
    },
    {
      "cpe_vendor": "microsoft",
      "cpe_product": "pocket_internet_explorer"
    }
  ],
  "vendor_binary_information": [],
  "cpe_application_names": [
    "Microsoft Internet Explorer",
    "Microsoft Internet Explorer 4.0.1 SP1",
    "Microsoft Internet Explorer 4.0.1 SP2",
    "Microsoft Internet Explorer 4.0 Platform Preview 1.0 (PP1)",
    "Microsoft Internet Explorer 4.01 Service Pack 1 (Windows 98)",
    "Microsoft Internet Explorer 5.0.1 SP3",
    "...etc"
  ],
  "cpes": [
    {
      "product_version": null,
      "cpe_uri": "cpe:/a:microsoft:ie",
      "cpe_uri_format": "2.2"
    },
    {
      "product_version": "4.0.1",
      "cpe_uri": "cpe:/a:microsoft:ie:4.0.1:sp1",
      "cpe_uri_format": "2.2"
    },
    {
      "product_version": "4.0.1",
      "cpe_uri": "cpe:/a:microsoft:ie:4.0.1:sp2",
      "cpe_uri_format": "2.2"
    },
    ...etc
  ]
}

parameters.name: cpe_vendor
parameters.description: The specified vendor being requested, extracted from CPE URI.

parameters.name: cpe_title
parameters.description: The specified product title/name requested, fuzzy matches records using product title.

cpe_normalized_application_names: Microsoft Office Service Pack 2 on X86
cpe_application_names: Microsoft Office 2013 Service Pack 2 on X86
Microsoft Office 2021 Long Term Servicing Channel (LTSC) Edition for MacOS

get.summary: CPE mappings by vendor and product
get.description:
Returns Common Platform Enumeration (CPE) information associated with the provided CPE vendor and product values.

🚧

Restricted Access

This API endpoint is a premium feature for selected partners.

CPE vendor and product names come from CPE URIs. These can come from several sources: An entry on NVD, the CPE dictionary or the results of a previous call to the Inference API.

An example from the CPE dictionary looks like this: 


[cpe-item name="cpe:/a:microsoft:office:2007"]
  [title xml:lang="en-US"]Microsoft Office 2007[/title]
  [meta:item-metadata nvd-id="38081" status="FINAL" modification-date="2008-04-15T23:55:38.437Z"/]
[/cpe-item]

In this case the CPE URI is "cpe:/a:microsoft:office:2007". The cpe_vendor is "microsoft", and the cpe_title is "office":'

/v2/application_mappings/find_by_cpe_title?cpe_vendor=microsoft&cpe_title=office

Results:


{
  "cpe_normalized_application_names": [
    "Microsoft Office",
    "Microsoft Office SP3",
    "Microsoft Office Professional",
    "Microsoft Office Service Pack 2 on X86"
    ...etc
  ],
  "cpe_mappings": [
    {
      "cpe_vendor": "microsoft",
      "cpe_product": "office"
    }
  ],
  "vendor_binary_information": [
    {
      "vendor": "Microsoft Corporation",
      "product": "Microsoft Office"
    },
    {
      "vendor": "Microsoft Corporation",
      "product": "Microsoft® Office"
    },
    {
      "vendor": "Microsoft Office",
      "product": "Microsoft Office"
    },
    ...etc
  ],
  "cpe_application_names": [
    "Microsoft Office",
    "Microsoft Office 2013 Service Pack 2 on X86",
    "Microsoft Office 2019 on x64",
    "Microsoft Office 2019 on x86",
    "Microsoft Office 2021 Long Term Servicing Channel (LTSC) Edition for MacOS"
    ...etc
  ],
  "cpes": [
    {
      "product_version": "2000",
      "cpe_uri": "cpe:/a:microsoft:office:2000:sp1",
      "cpe_uri_format": "2.2"
    },
    {
      "product_version": "2021",
      "cpe_uri": "cpe:/a:microsoft:office:2021::~~ltsc~macos~~",
      "cpe_uri_format": "2.2"
    },
    {
      "product_version": "2013",
      "cpe_uri": "cpe:/a:microsoft:office:2013::~~click-to-run~~x64~",
      "cpe_uri_format": "2.2"
    }
    ...etc
  ]
}

parameters.name: cpe_vendor
parameters.description: The specified vendor being requested, extracted from CPE URI.

parameters.name: cpe_product
parameters.description: The specified product being requested, extracted from CPE URI.

cpe_normalized_application_names: Microsoft Office Service Pack 2 on X86
cpe_application_names: Microsoft Office 2013 Service Pack 2 on X86
Microsoft Office 2021 Long Term Servicing Channel (LTSC) Edition for MacOS

get.summary: Find all CPE vendor names from a plaintext vendor name
get.description:
Returns the CPE vendor names from CPE URIs associated with a vendor name extracted from a distributable binary

🚧

Restricted Access

This API endpoint is a premium feature for selected partners.

Given a vendor name: Google LLC 


/v2/application_mappings/find_cpe_vendors_by_vendor_name?vendor_name=Google LLC

Results:

{
  "cpe_vendors": [
    "google",
    "google_llc"
  ]
}

get.summary: Find products associated with a CPE's vendor name
get.description:
Returns CPE product names associated with the provided vendor name

🚧

Restricted Access

This API endpoint is a premium feature for selected partners.

CPE URI: 


cpe:/a:microsoft:office:2007

Using the vendor part from the above CPE URI, "microsoft", we can return all the products associated with that vendor 


/v2/application_mappings/find_cpe_products_by_vendor_cpe?cpe_vendor=microsoft

{
  "cpe_products": [
    "visio",
    "visual_studio_2015",
    "excel_web_app_2013",
    "wordpad",
    "visual_studio_2017",
    "internet_explorer",
    ...etc
  ]
}

parameters.name: cpe_vendor
parameters.description: The vendor being requested, extracted from CPE URI.

post.summary: Vulnerability Inference for Darwin-based Operating Systems
post.description:
Returns a list of known vulnerabilities for a given Darwin-based operating system such as OS X.

🚧

Restricted Access

This API endpoint is a premium feature for select partners.

To generate a payload on the client machine, run this osquery command from your command line shell:

osqueryi --json "SELECT * FROM os_version;"

The command should produce JSON output that looks like this:

[
  {
    "major": "10",
    "name": "Mac OS X",
    "platform_like": "darwin",
    "patch": "3",
    "platform": "darwin",
    "version": "10.15.1",
    "build": "19D76",
    "codename": "",
    "arch": "x86_64",
    "minor": "15"
  }
]

The above output can be used in the POST request.

cve.description: An out-of-bounds read was addressed with improved bounds checking. This issue is fixed in macOS Catalina 10.15.7, Security Update 2020-005 High Sierra, Security Update 2020-005 Mojave, iOS 14.0 and iPadOS 14.0. Processing a maliciously crafted USD file may lead to unexpected application termination or arbitrary code execution.

fixes.product_name: macOS Catalina 10.15.7 Security Update 2020-005 High Sierra Security Update 2020-005 Mojave

fixes.impact: Processing a maliciously crafted USD file may lead to unexpected application termination or arbitrary code execution

post.description:
Returns a list of known vulnerabilities for a given list of applications. Supported operating systems include CentOS, SUSE Linux Enterprise Server, Redhat Enterprise Linux, Ubuntu and Windows.

🚧

Restricted Access

This API endpoint is a premium feature for select partners.

post.summary: Vulnerability Inference for Microsoft Operating Systems
post.description:
Returns a list of known vulnerabilities for a given Windows operating system version.

🚧

Restricted Access

This API endpoint is a premium feature for select partners.

example.cve_description: A memory corruption vulnerability exists in the Windows DHCP clientwhen an attacker sends specially crafted DHCP responses to a client, aka 'Windows DHCP Client Remote Code Execution Vulnerability'. This CVE ID is unique from CVE-2019-0698, CVE-2019-0726.
